results.title: The Best Remaining Seats
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
John Baxter, well known Australian historian and cinema critic, examines the fall of the great cinema houses, how the Hollywood industry built them and Hollywood acted as a magnet for both talent and money. Charlie Chaplin’s career is also analysed. This episode is one of the “Filmstruck” series which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.

results.title: A Murder is announced
results.creator_credit: David Giles, Guy Slater and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
Everyone in Chipping Cleghorn thinks that the advertisement in the local paper is a joke - but the villagers are intrigued by this new style of party game, and turn out in force at the appointed hour. They are not disappointed. As the clock strikes seven, the lights go out, the door to the drawing room swings open, a torch beam plays around the room - and three shots ring out. Then a body slumps at the door. It is no longer a game. Inspector Craddock and everyone present agree that the dead man shot himself. Miss Marple thinks differently. Stars Joan Hickson as Miss Marple.

results.title: Talking to the Moon
results.creator_credit: Franco Di Chiera, Margaret Smith and SBS-TV
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
A group of Australians are taken back to the quarantine station which was their first experience of their new country when they arrived as migrants. A labyrinth of cold, tiny cubicles enclosed by imposing stone walls the quarantine station was, for over 50 years, the first Australian home for thousands of immigrants. Through interviews with women and men who passed the station we gain an understanding of the hardships undergone by migrants in their initial years in a new land.

results.title: The Restless planet
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description:
Episode number 2 of Series “Earth revealed”.
The creation of the planets in our solar system has had an enormous impact on the geological structure of the Earth,and the existence of life on the planet. This episode examines the origins of the solar system and planets, and how the Earth and its atmosphere evolved. The Earth and its inter-relationship with the planets is also examined.

results.title: Other People's Money
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Part Three of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, explains that without the Hollywood studios’ money independent producers had to find backers. This program includes interviews with top Australian producers.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Part Three of a ten part documentary “Filmstruck”, which considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience. In this episode, John Baxter, well known Australian film historian and cinema critic, explains that without the Hollywood studios’ money independent producers had to find backers. This program includes interviews with top Australian producers.

This program includes interviews with top Australian producers.

results.title: 4.50 from Paddington
results.creator_credit: Martyn Friend, George Gallaccio and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
Elspeth McGillicuddy travels from London to St. Mary Mead to visit her old friend Miss Marple, catching the 4.50 train from Paddington. On the way the train draws to a halt and another train draws alongside. In the carriage opposite the blind suddenly snaps up. Glancing across, Mrs McGillicuddy witnesses a sight she will never forget. Almost immediately the train chugs away, leaving the image printed in Mrs. McGillicuddy’s mind - she has witnessed a murder! Stars Joan Hickson as Miss Marple.
results.description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.

Glancing across, Mrs McGillicuddy witnesses a sight she will never forget. Almost immediately the train chugs away, leaving the image printed in Mrs. McGillicuddy’s mind - she has witnessed a murder! results.title: Earth revealed
results.creator_credit: Robert Lattanzio and Corporation for Community Television
results.brief_description: This 26 part series overviews the fields of geology and the earth sciences. Discusses earthquakes, volcanoes, continental drift, the formation of the sea and the Earth’s resources in short but informative episodes.

results.title: Beyond the ivory towers
results.creator_credit: Karla Fritis, Margaret Smith and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian mosaic”.
This program looks at artists and political protest, using as a focus the exhibition “Towers of torture” held at Sydney University’s Tin Shed Gallery in 1988. Artists, including Bernard Smith, Ruth Waller, Clem Milward, Bruce Petty and George Gittoes had been asked to contribute works which protested Alan Bond’s involvement with the Pinochet regime. As well as discussing the specific issue of Chile, Professor Bernard Smith and art critic Charles Merewether discuss the role of the artist in social and political protest, with particular reference to Australian art.
results.creator_credit_for_label: Karla Fritis, Margaret Smith and Australia. Special Broadcasting Service

results.title: A Pocketful of Rye
results.creator_credit: Guy Slater, George Gallaccio and BBC
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Miss Marple Series”.
In this sinister tale, set in the 1940’s, Miss Marple sets about unravelling the mysterious murder of city financier, Rex Fortesque. When the cause of death is identified as poisoning, suspicion falls on the occupants of the family home, Yew Tree Lodge. But the police are perplexed as the only clue to the murder is a handful of rye in the dead man’s pocket. However, when another murder shortens the life of suspects, the connection with the nursery rhyme “Sing a Song of Sixpence” is all too clear to Miss Marple.

results.title: You Can't Say That
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Filmstruck Series”.
Oh! The problems of censorship! John Baxter shows, from the days of seemingly innocuous material such as the Keystone Cops to the present, that there have been recurrent problems with Censorship boards. This program, part of a ten part documentary, Filmstruck, considers the impact of cinema on the social and personal life of the viewing audience.
